Award.AwardTitle: Belmont Forum-G8 Initiative Collaborative Research: Maintaining productivity and incomes in the Tonle Sap fishery in the face of climate change
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support to U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by a 13-country initiative on global change research through the Belmont Forum and the G8 countries Heads of Research Councils. The Belmont Forum is a high level group of the world?s major and emerging funders of global environmental change research and international science councils. It aims to accelerate delivery of the international environmental research most urgently needed to remove critical barriers to sustainability by aligning and mobilizing international resources. The G8 Heads of Research Councils developed a funding framework to support multilateral research projects that address global challenges in ways that are beyond the capacity of national or bilateral activities. Each partner country provides funding for their researchers within a consortium to alleviate the need for funds to cross international borders. This approach facilitates effective leveraging of national resources to support excellent research on topics of global relevance best tackled through a multinational approach, recognizing that global challenges need global solutions.

Working together in an inaugural call of the International Opportunities Fund, the Belmont Forum and G8HORCs have provided support for research projects that seek to deliver knowledge needed for action to mitigate and adapt to detrimental environmental change and extreme hazardous events that relate to either Freshwater Security or Coastal Vulnerability. This award provides support for the U.S. researchers to cooperate in consortia that consist of partners from at least three of the participating countries and that bring together natural scientists, social scientists and research users (e.g., policy makers, regulators, NGOs, communities and industry).

This award supports research activities that will deliver new understanding of climate change responses and management options of freshwater indiscriminate fisheries. Freshwater fisheries provide food security and income for hundreds of millions of people worldwide in some of the poorest countries on the planet. These fisheries are composed of diverse assemblages of species and indiscriminate fishing practices. Indiscriminate fishing practices are likely to have important but yet unconsidered implications for the sustainability and management of ecosystems. This project will (1) construct a general theory to understand the social and ecological implications of indiscriminate fisheries under climate changes and (2) develop and test this theory in the economically and socially important Tonle Sap fishery in Cambodia. The Tonle Sap Lake is one of the largest and most productive indiscriminate fisheries in the world, receiving large annual flood pulses from the Mekong River. Recent changes in fisheries regulations present the opportunity to understand how governance and management, climate, and ecology interact to regulate the sustainability and maintenance of food production. These efforts will contribute an understanding of the implications of indiscriminate fisheries and local governance structures and options have for millions living in Cambodia and for indiscriminate fisheries worldwide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Belmont Forum Tonle Sap and Climate Change project was designed to understand the implications of climate change for small-scale freshwater fisheries. These fisheries are the main protein source for millions of people worldwide and may be threatened by the joint effects of overfishing and climate change. The outcomes of these interacting factors are critical to the lives and livelihoods of millions of people living in poverty, especially in the tropics. The project addressed this challenge through the development of theory, testing the theory with fieldwork in the Tonle Sap lake in Cambodia and working with the users of the lake to use that information for better management.

The Tonle Sap is the great lake in the heart of Cambodia, just south of the majestic temple complex of Angkor Wat.  The lake is home for over three million people living on its shores or in floating villages.  It is a reservoir of incredible biodiversity, including a rich fish fauna and critically important waterbird habitat.  Striking a balance between conserving the natural values of the lake and the need for the fishery is an iconic problem for the Tonle Sap and many similar tropical freshwater fisheries.

The project created a collaboration of three research teams from the United States (Conservation International), Canada (University of Guelph), and France (Toulouse University), with participating researchers from over a dozen institutions. This unique trilateral collaboration is a hallmark of Belmont Forum-funded projects and created a dynamic multi-country research effort. Working with our partner university, the University of Battambang, in Cambodia we were able to train young researchers from four nations at the same time that the project generated important new information about the Tonle Sap and its fishery.

The theory developed by the project is called the theory of indiscriminate fisheries. It uses ecological theory to describe the effect of fishing all species and all size classes. This new theory was needed because most fisheries theory is built for large-scale marine fisheries that target single species and have very well-equipped boats. Freshwater fisheries like the Tonle Sap, in contrast, often have fishing fleets comprised of small non-motorized canoes, whose crew are all family members.

The fieldwork on the Tonle Sap found just what the theory predicted – indiscriminate fisheries create a kind of fish monoculture, similar to industrial agriculture. The food web in these fisheries is almost completely destroyed, with small fast-growing species dominating. The result is a large decrease in potential income from the fishery, but it may be the best way to maximize protein output of the fishery. In this way, the project theory helped show that there is a stark choice to be made for the Tonle Sap and other freshwater systems in the tropics – the choice between maximizing fishery revenue and maximizing protein production for people living in poverty.

The project then constructed computer models to simulate what might happen in the Tonle Sap due to overfishing, climate change, and upstream dam construction. The model showed that an indiscriminate fishery which maximizes protein offtake, like an agricultural monoculture, is very susceptible to the year-to-year changes in climatic conditions. Since fish at the base of the food web are feeding on primary productivity, and primary productivity is directly controlled by environmental conditions, the near absence of a food web means that changes in primary productivity due to changes in climatic conditions will be transmitted much more immediately and directly to the fishery.

This heightened sensitivity of the fishery can be both accentuated and buffered by dams upstream. The project models showed that in some years dams may help even out environmental changes that would cause peaks and valleys in fishery production. But in other years, dams are likely to accentuate the loss of floodplain habitat in the Tonle Sap and cause a decrease in the fishery.

A surprising finding was that protected areas, in which fishing is prohibited, can help increase the fish catch and help protect the fishery from the ups and downs caused by dams and climate change. This is because no-fishing areas restore some of the resiliency that is lost due to damage to the food web.  The more intensively an indiscriminate fishery is fished, the more benefit no-fishing protected areas deliver.

There is much still to be learned about the Tonle Sap, its fishery, and indiscriminate fisheries worldwide. The Tonle Sap and Climate Change project has shown that the very poor people reliant on these fisheries are likely facing greater ups and downs in income and food availability due to the interactions of overfishing, climate change, and dams. Programs can help improve this situation by rebuilding the foodweb and fishery, using protected areas to increase catch and protect fishing from year-to-year variations, and diversifying income so that impoverished families are not highly dependent on a variable resource.
